title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer to receive pay off half the size of Jose Mourinho's if Man Utd sack him

Man Utd will reportedly have to fork out £7 million in compensation to Ole Gunnar Solskjaer if they sack him, less than a year after they paid £19.6m to Jose Mourinho.

The Norwegian succeeded Mourinho as United boss in December last year, and a flying start prompted the club's board to offer him a permanent deal.

However United have had a remarkable slump since, picking up just 17 points in as many games in the league.

By contrast rivals Liverpool have won all of their last 17 matches, and top the table after eight wins this season.

United meanwhile are languishing in 12th having already lost three matches, with Solskjaer now under pressure to get results.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

The 46-year-old has overseen the club's worst start to a season in 30 years - with their next match against Liverpool at Old Trafford on October 20.

Should United fail to get a result in that match, they would be in danger of slipping closer to the bottom three, and potentially costing Solskjaer his job.

He would receive a hefty pay out from United if they relieve him of his duties however, earning a little more than a years wages, according to the Sun .

Solskjaer is 7/4 on with bookmakers to be the next Premier League manager to be sacked, with only Everton's Marco Silva ahead of him at evens.

(Image: Getty Images)

Mourinho had only signed a new contract in January 2018 which would have taken him to the summer of 2020.

The Portuguese coach was on a mammoth £15 million a year when he and his staff were axed.

United chiefs were keen not to make the same mistake this time, with Solskjaer on £6m a year.

It would be the latest in a line of pay offs by United, after they reportedly gave David Moyes £5.2 million, and Louis van Gaal and his team £8.4 million when they departed the club.

United executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward has offered his backing to Solskjaer, but United are rumoured to be eyeing a potential replacement .

The Mail report that RB Leipzig boss Julian Nagelsmann, 32, has been pinpointed as a future candidate for the role.
description: The Norwegian is under pressure at Old Trafford after a poor start to the season and just 17 points from their last 17 games
